Topic.Title: IF THE WEEKLY INVENTORY ENERGY REPORTS SHOW HUGE GLUT BUILDS: OIL WILL CRASH MORE/AMZN WILL SKY

Message.Msg: NAS, let me introduce you to the concept of a valuation on fundamentals. The value of a company should reflect the discounted value of all future cash flows. Looking at a highly volatile ST move in oil prices lower (despite your best attempts) means nothing to the expected value of gasoline prices that should be used in a rigorous bottom up model by investors. Gasoline prices, outside of the great recession, has been systematically increasing for a decade. Absent another great recession, they will continue their inexorable rise upward, and Amazon's competitiveness will decline. A few day drop which brings us part of the way back to where prices were but a month ago solves nothing. In fact, through the first two months of this quarter, Amazon will have results reflecting gas prices that have never been higher for the YOY comp. Institutional longs can choose to put their head in the ground and be completely negligent with others' money by blindly holding or worse yet, accumulating. Or, they can recognize this as the biggest bubble in the market today and use this as currency to buy stocks that are not in a bubble (those that keep the market multiple low enough for the talking heads on CNBC to continue arguing the case that the market is cheap).

Topic.Title: IF THE WEEKLY INVENTORY ENERGY REPORTS SHOW HUGE GLUT BUILDS: OIL WILL CRASH MORE/AMZN WILL SKY

Message.Msg: Bernanke's "wealth effect" is about maintaining consumer confidence and thus supporting the economy. It is BS and will not work. 10% of the people control roughly 80% of the financial assets. Thus, the market cannot sustain consumption. And, as soon as it stops going up, the psychological lift falters and any benefit is lost. No, the channel through which POMO is supporting the stock market is not via the impact on fundamentals via a confident consumer. It is a direct transfer to the MM and is being used to kill volatility and create the appearance of safety, so that the TBTF institutions can unload via the upper deck (with the help of the quants). This too shall eventually fail because $85B a month will not be enough as the total market capitalization grows and real world fundamentals (personal disposable income) degrade. This has nothing to do with the consumer...

Prices do not come down because the marginal buyer is overseas...

Topic.Title: Amazon will be next Apple

Message.Msg: "Amazon is a ponzi scheme." Tech, you do yourself a diservice. Anyone who knows what a ponzi scheme is, and what Amazon is, knows that Amazon is NOT a ponzi scheme. "A Ponzi scheme is a fraudulent investment operation that pays returns to its investors from their own money or the money paid by subsequent investors, rather than from profit earned by the individual or organization running the operation." Amazon does not pay returns to the investors, so Amazon can't be a ponzi scheme. Amazon does not receive money from investors, so Amazon can't be a ponzi scheme. Amazon is a company that actually does stuff, for example I buy from them regularly, so Amazon can't be a ponzi scheme. I know you're frustrated with all the money you've lost betting against Amazon, especially when a dumb hillbilly can make money in Amazon, but lets try to be a little accurate, ok?

Topic.Title: Amazon will be next Apple

Message.Msg: If you read my follow-up post, I made clear that Amazon itself is not a Ponzi scheme...

Topic.Title: Next quarter results will show millions of losses. This company will never make profit!

Message.Msg: Correct. I am but one who recognizes the profound and permanent damage that is being done to our markets by these predatory moves. I've been wrong short term, just as I was with NFLX, GMCR and CMG. But, ultimately, I was proved correct there and will be here as well... The difference Nas is that I am risking my own money. Not taking massive risk with other people's money in a speculative greater fool play. There is no scenario where Amazon is anything but a bubble. Best case, AAPL is used as cash to support this for another quarter before the rush to the exits. Smart money will get out before that (and before earnings) because the valuation gap is simply too large to sustain. I do hope the new SEC/FBI team nails the folks behind this. And, I will certainly do what I can to assist any investigation that were ever to arise. These games destroy trust in the market (I know plenty of AAPL shareholders who are #$%$ right now... and are pulling money from the market). See the latest retail flows... That is the collateral damage caused by these games. They add no value. They are simply glorified theft. When something creates no value but extract much, it eventually craters or incites a major backlash. In all likelihood, both are coming...

Topic.Title: Next quarter results will show millions of losses. This company will never make profit!

Message.Msg: Ultimately, the people with all the assets will realize that social stability trumps getting the last dollar. And, as I pointed out a week or so ago, that is what is ultimately at risk. This is all being done to avoid banks and asset holders from writing off losses. But, the net result is a tax on the general population (higher housing prices is a tax on new buyers, food and energy inflation disproportionately affects the 80% of the population making less than 100K a year). The approach being taken can ONLY lead to social instability over time. Beyond that, it simply cannot work in a consumption driven economy... But, that will become clear in time...

Topic.Title: Next quarter results will show millions of losses. This company will never make profit!

Message.Msg: Not going to defend Bernanke. I think he is a train wreck. I think Greenspan was an even bigger train wreck (the video of him saying only stock prices matter was over the top...). You can mock me all you want on this stock, but I understand what is really happening in the global economy and why it is happening now. All the central bank intervention cannot fix what is wrong. It will fail. We are not living in the 90's or the early 2000's. This reflation attempt comes at a very different point in history. Most of the folks managing money are going to get crushed because they live in the financial economy and not the real one. The believe the self referential groupthink that is constantly repeated. But, repeating it doesn't change the underlying fundamental drivers that have brought us to where we are.

Message.Title: kind of a blah day of consolidation : my formula for the weekly bears forceast on weekly max pain is usually add 10 points to AMZN
Message.Msg: yes it usually closes 10 points higher than any of the lower move prediction that I've ever see to meet their exepcted weekly max pain targets. My big question to options trader of weeklys moneths or quarterlys, is when was the last time AMZN closed BELOW max pain. I would think it almost never has. Maybe in November 2011 when it had the jolt of 247 and bottomed at 166.97 but not since. Just wondering. Very tough to play the put game in AMZN on the purchase side. Probably equivalent to be dragged by a rope though rocks and soil by a bunch of Clydesdales, where the powers that control the stock are the Clydesdales.

Topic.Title: FBI and SEC team up...

Message.Msg: It's up for the FBI/SEC to determine what is illegal and what is not. But, the Fed's balance sheet expansion does not render all securities laws null and void... BTW, I haven't said this is illegal. I have said it is wildly predatory and destroys trust in the market to have AAPL systematically crushed while MOMO float jam scams fly. I have also said I would love to see the FBI/SEC take a good hard look at the AAPL/AMZN trade made here. I suspect that Nanex, armed with the consolidated feed on both the underlying and options, could demonstrate purposeful manipulation. In the end, I doubt there will be any legal action. I expect the bubble to burst because the math doesn't work and this is simply a greater fool play. I'm looking forward to April earnings.

Topic.Title: CNBC...

Message.Msg: Not the full story. The technical guy said he did not like either company up here. Then he said if he had to pick a company on just the technicals he would take AMZN. The fundamental guy said GOOG and the technical guy agreed it's a better company. Technically I'm sure AMZN looks better since it has been consolidating in this same zone for a while and earnings won't be announced for a while but those usually don't matter either because the sell side analysts will make up a new metric as a reason to raise the price target even if sales come in closer to $15B vs. the current analyst estimate of $16.2B. They tend to not kill the golden gooses like AMZN. Now on a relative basis if you asked me to pick between AMZN here or CRM or NFLX right now I would take AMZN but fundamentally I don't like any of them. Good luck.

Topic.Title: Google Is Building A Same-Day Amazon Prime Competitor, “Google Shopping Express”

Message.Msg: Definitely, AMAZON retail will see big impact. Today there is also a news about BestBuy price matching effect. The research and result found that price matching works for BestBuy because sales tax advantage for Amazon is gone. More consumers would like to buy from the local retails for the convenience of return and exchange.
